entry.title: First Half 2025 Release: What is New for SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals?
entry.content:
We‚Äôre thrilled to share what is new for SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals as part of the 1H 2025 product release. We are unveiling a modern and refreshed performance form experience designed with your feedback in mind, new AI capabilities, and enhancements to continuous performance management capabilities. All built to help you focus on what matters most‚Äîyour people.

We are excited to unveil the new performance form experience with a new interface and several AI-assisted capabilities designed to improve efficiency and support more consistent, high-quality evaluations. The layout has been updated to be more responsive and easier to navigate. Information panels now appear only when needed, providing context‚Äîsuch as historical comments or rating guidance‚Äîwithout crowding the screen. The result is a cleaner, more task-focused interface that reduces unnecessary scrolling and helps users stay focused while completing reviews.


Enhanced performance form experience

This redesigned experience also includes AI-assisted comments feature, which suggests well-crafted, insightful starter comments that align with the ratings provided on skills, goals, and competencies. These serve as a starting point and helps evaluators provide constructive, growth-centric feedback, reducing the effort required to write detailed feedback, especially in large-scale reviews. That is not all. This experience also offers AI-assisted feedback in performance reviews, which helps refine and improve communications by integrating rating context and user input to make performance form feedback more relevant and precise.


AI-assisted comments feature


AI-assisted feedback in performance reviews

For managers, this new experience provides AI-assisted performance insights. This feature analyzes a wealth of talent data from continuous feedback to achievements, to the mid-year performance assessment and summarizes the employee‚Äôs strengths, achievements, and areas for improvement. This feature gives managers a quick yet comprehensive understanding of an employee‚Äôs performance with actionable recommendations tailored to each employee's strengths and areas for improvement.


AI-assisted performance insights

With this release, we are also introducing AI-based sentiment analysis for 360-degree reviews to help employees quickly identify positive, negative or mixed feedback, highlighting areas that need improvement and enabling focused professional development. This makes it easier to spot areas that require attention or improvement without having to manually sift through each comment. It also helps highlight areas where the employee is consistently recognized, which can be useful for both motivation and development planning.


AI-based sentiment analysis for 360-degree reviews

And for continuous performance management, employees can now link activities and achievements across various goal plans, leveraging greater flexibility to reflect everyday efforts and evolving priorities across the organization. This helps ensure comprehensive alignment with organization‚Äôs priorities as they evolve throughout the year, especially when activities fall under different strategic goals.


Link achievements and activities to multiple goal plans feature

Want to See It in Action?

Check out this short demo video that describes the updated experience and highlights how these innovations and enhancements work in practice. You can also visit the SAP SuccessFactors 1H 2025 Product Release page to download the full release brochure, overview video featuring Bianka Woelke, and more.

All product features and delivery dates mentioned in this document represent current product development expectations only and not a delivery commitment. You should base your purchasing, administrative, and configuration decisions solely on functionality that is currently available.

entry.title: Implementation of SAP Task Center for ERP ECC Systems (Non-S/4HANA using Third Party Connector)
entry.content:
Simplify Task Management with SAP Task Center‚Äôs Third Party Connector

Looking to simplify and centralize task handling across multiple ERP systems, including non-SAP platforms? With the SAP Task Center's Third Party Connector, you can seamlessly integrate non-SAP systems into a unified task management hub. Experience dynamic task filters, multi-language support, mass approvals, custom attributes, and much more‚Äîall in a single interface tailored to your needs.

We‚Äôve successfully implemented and validated the SAP Task Center Third Party Connector for SAP ERP systems (non-S/4HANA). The POC was based on the great and detailed implementation Guidelines provided by SAP.

Proven Results with SAP ERP Systems (Non-S/4HANA)

We‚Äôve successfully implemented and validated the SAP Task Center Third Party Connector for SAP ERP (non-S/4HANA) systems. Using SAP‚Äôs detailed Third-Party Adoption Guide, our proof of concept (PoC) demonstrated how the Task Center can efficiently manage tasks from diverse systems, creating a scalable and flexible solution for heterogeneous landscapes.

This article outlines the implementation of a Third Party Connector for ERP systems based on official SAP documentation. We‚Äôll cover the fundamental configuration steps, highlight the achieved results, and showcase the benefits of this solution.

Prerequisites

In fact the integration of any Third Party System needs to fulfill the following prerequisites:

  1. Interface definition as described in the adoption guideline provided by SAP. Having a deeper look on the definition it is mostly an oData v4 standard service
    SAP Task Center Third-Party Adoption Guide 
  2. User Mapping between local user id and ID in IAS / CIS to assign tasks to the correct SCIM Global User ID. This could also be handled in a dedicated middleware.
  3. Technical access to provide capabilities of the interface, task definitions and tasks as described here
    SAP Documentation: Primary Destination with Technical User Third-Party Task Provider
    The primary destination ensures secure and reliable communication between the Task Provider and the Task Center, using a technical user for authentication.
  4. Single Sign On access for read further details like description, attachments, comments and to execute the actions on the tasks like approve or reject. Check the following link for more details:
    SAP Documentation: Secondary Destination for Principal Propagation Third-Party Task Provider
    This destination ensures proper user context propagation, allowing actions in the Task Center to be executed on behalf of the authenticated user.

All feature of a Third Party Connector, like attachment, comments, bulk or substitutions can be implemented step by step and switch on after implementation.

Implementation and Architecture

The implementation was split into three parts

  • SAP BTP based Cloud Foundry Service to handle the requests (mainly oData v4)
  • SAP ERP Task Center Backend Service (odata v2) to handle the requests from BTP based on a technical user
  • SAP Standard Task Processing Service used by Standard My Inbox Application to handle the SSO based requests

The following image shows up the final architecture of the implementation:

Integrating SAP Standard Task Processing Standard Service pushed the speed of the development dramatically. We didn't had to cover standard actions, like

  • Reading Attachments, Comments, Description of the task
  • Claiming, Forwarding Tasks
  • Performing Actions (approve, reject a.s.o.) on tasks
  • Integrate Detail Screens as used in My Inbox Scenarios (e.g. Approve Leave Request V3)

Now we are focusing on decoupling the Task Processing Service and moving more and more functionalities to our implementation. The following screen shows the integration the Approve Leave Request V3 Service in the Task Center:

The screen is split into three parts

  1. Task Center View
  2. My Inbox Scenario "Approve Leave Request V3"
  3. Task Center Actions to execute them directly via Task Center

Achievements and Features

The implementation of the connector brings numerous benefits that significantly enhance task management:

1. Connector Setup for Standard ERP Systems

The connector enables the integration of tasks from ERP systems that are not based on S/4HANA, bridging the gap to modern task management.

2. Dynamic Task Filters

Through destinations, task filters can be flexibly configured, allowing users to view only the tasks relevant to them. This improves usability and reduces complexity. Additional filter parameter can be passed by configuring the destination properties to the backend logic in order to display dedicated tasks in a separate group e.g. Leave Request Only and to reuse the connector.

3. Multi-Language Support

The application supports multiple languages, which is especially advantageous for globally operating companies. Users can view tasks in their preferred language.

4. Inplace Display of Decision Scenarios (e.g. My Inbox Detail Screens)

Tasks such as leave requests can be directly displayed and processed within the Task Center without switching applications, enhancing efficiency and providing a seamless user experience. We are delivering enhancement spots to adjust the displayed content and integrate dedicated approval screens inplace

Inplace Approval View

Standard View

5. Custom Attributes

The connector supports displaying and processing custom attributes tailored to specific business requirements. This allows to take fast decisions especially when performing mass approvals.

6. Mass Approvals (Bulk Actions)

Users can approve multiple tasks simultaneously, reducing the workload for repetitive tasks (e.g., invoice approvals).

7. Substitution Rules

Tasks can be forwarded to substitutes during absences, ensuring uninterrupted workflows.

8. Additional Features

These include support for task delegation, adaptability to specific business needs, and the ability to integrate tasks from additional systems.

Flexibility and Scalability

With the Third Party Connector, SAP Task Center becomes a versatile platform for task management. It‚Äôs not limited to ERP systems‚Äîyou can also integrate CRM, HR, and further custom or non SAP applications, ensuring a truly centralized and scalable solution for diverse business environments.

Next Steps

More integrations are on the way! If you‚Äôre interested in learning how the SAP Task Center Third Party Connector can transform your task management, feel free to reach out directly:

Connect with Christoph Kuczera on LinkedIn

Let‚Äôs simplify and scale your task management together! üòä

entry.title: How to request ONB 1.0 Super Admin Access Request for SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Onb Super Admin Access or also known as Onb back-end access

Consultants working on the Onboarding Implementation need this access.  Super Admin site access is required for managing the customer Account.

This request has to be raised only by the consultant certified in C-THR91 or C_THR97 with Partner S user ID via https://hcmcloudops.successfactors.com/

Customers are not allowed access to this portal, even if they try, they will get an Error ‚ÄúERROR! You have logged in as user Sxxxxxxxxxx belonging to company  XXXXXX  Inc.‚Äù

Partner with P id is also not allowed to access this portal, they will get an Error ‚ÄúERROR! You have logged in as user Pxxxxxxxxxx belonging to partner XXXXXX Inc‚Äù

It involves 2 simple steps

Step 1 (Customer Step)

The customer needs to send the below email, including all instances [Environment(s) : Preview, Dev, Prod] in a single email to the consultant, keeping in mind a few key points

  • Must include the consultant's full name and Partner email address
  • Approval should be in English
  • Customer Approver signature needs to include full name, job position, email, and phone number
  • Attachment must be in a non-editable format, e.g. *.msg/*.eml/*.mht of the approval email.  If your organization does not use MS Outlook, then provide a screenshot(s) of the approval email and attach it to the request. MS Word or other editable documents will not be accepted

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From:  abcd@qwer.com  (customer)
To: aaaabbbccc@xcde1234.com (consultant)

Subject: SuccessFactors ONB Super Admin Access Approval for <CUSTOMER Name>

I understand SuccessFactors adheres to strict policies concerning access to customer environments. I confirm the approval for CONSULTANT of <PARTNER COMPANY> named below to be provided ONB Super Admin access to my organization‚Äôs implementation with details below.

Customer Name: <CUSTOMER Name>
Customer ID: <CUSTOMER ID>
ONB Account Names (aka ONB Company IDs):  <ONB Account Names>
Environment(s):  <e.g., DC2 Production, DC2 Preview, DC2 Development>  (list all instance you want to give access)
Consultant Name: Mr./Ms. AAAA  BBB  CCC 
Consultant Email: aaaabbbccc@xcde1234.com

Customer Approver's Signature:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Step 2 (Consultant Step)

  1. Log in to https://hcmcloudops.successfactors.com/
  2. Go to the Operation Requests tab
  3. Under ONB Requests, click ONB 1.0 Super Admin Access Request
  4. Click ‚ÄòProceed‚Äô on the Certification Required Warning
  5. Provide the mandatory details required by the request form, such as Customer Name, ONB Account, Data Center location, and Environment, and attach the approval email and submit

For finding ONB Account, it will appear as ‚ÄúAccount ID‚Äù in BizX Provisioning> Company Settings > Onboarding Settings

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2397304

entry.title: üêû SAP SuccessFactors Bug Report: Duplicate Transactions Triggered by the Escape Key
entry.content:
üìåOverview

SAP SuccessFactors is one of the most robust and widely used cloud-based HCM (Human Capital Management) suites in the market today. Its modular design, including Employee Central, Time Management, Recruiting, and Performance Management, allows businesses to manage their workforce efficiently. These modules are leveraged by thousands of organizations globally to manage day-to-day HR operations.

Given this extensive reach and the business-critical nature of the application, even low-severity bugs can have widespread implications. Ensuring a seamless, intuitive experience for end-users is essential for productivity and system trust.

Recently, a low-level yet recurring issue has been observed in commonly used transactions related to time and employee data management:

  • View Time Sheet for [Employee]

  • Administer Time for [Employee]

  • View Job Information for [Employee]

  • View Name for [Employee]

  • View Employment Information for [Employee]

     

    ‚ö†Ô∏èThe Bug: Duplicate Transactions When Pressing ESC Key

    When performing tasks in View Time Sheet or Administer Time, pressing the Escape (ESC) key ‚Äî a standard user behavior intended to clear transaction ‚Äî triggers a duplicate instance of the transaction

    üîÑSteps to Reproduce:

    1. Log in to SAP SuccessFactors.

    2. Navigate to either Administer Time or View Time Sheet.

    3. Press Escape Key After entering the Transaction

    4. Result: The same transaction is re-invoked automatically

    ‚Äå‚ÄåCall to Action for SAP Product Team

    Given the nature of this issue and its presence in key transactional areas, it is imperative that the SAP SuccessFactors product team evaluates and addresses this behavior as part of their ongoing commitment to usability and system stability. Even minor inconsistencies in expected user interactions‚Äîsuch as the misuse of the ESC key‚Äîcan erode user confidence and introduce inefficiencies at scale. We recommend this be flagged for review and inclusion in a future maintenance release or patch cycle.

entry.title: Exploring SAP ERP: A Complete Guide to Key Modules and Business Processes
entry.content:
SAP ERP Modules Explained

Initially, when I coming to know SAP, I had no idea about ERP, MM, SD, FI, etc. So, I took the time to learn these concepts, and that's why I‚Äôd like to share what I‚Äôve learned. I believe this will definitely be helpful for understanding how ERP works. SAP ERP is an enterprise resource planning system that integrates core business processes across Organization. This blog covers an overview of SAP ERP core modules and concepts ideal for both beginners and professionals looking to refresh their knowledge.

ERP Module Categories

Technical Modules

Technical modules involve the development of SAP modules, which can be categorized as standard or custom. Standard modules can be extended based on requirements, and custom modules can be developed to meet new requirements. This process includes designing the system architecture.

Functional Modules

Function Modules are between the end user and business which I elaborate in below 

Master Data vs Transactional Data

  • Master Data: This is static data like customer, material, or supplier records.
  • Transactional Data: This is a dynamic data which changed constantly for every transaction like purchase orders, sales orders, and invoices. For both master and transactional data below is the example and what they record during the process.

Understanding SAP Clients

A Client that Holds the separate system for the different scenario like development, quality, production, sandbox, support, Quality for support and they name it as different as D52, P52 etc. it differs from organization to organization.

Types of SAP Clients:

  1. Production ‚Äì Live environment
  2. Quality Assurance (QA) ‚Äì For testing
  3. Development - For developing 
  4. Sandbox ‚Äì For experimentation
  5. Training ‚Äì For end-user training

SAP Security Roles

Security has complete control over who can access what, and they have the sole authority to make those decisions. For example, developers cannot access every transaction available in SAP Logon they have certain restrictions.

Access Control Can Be Based On:

  • Company Code
  • Plant
  • Sales Organization
  • Transaction Codes (allowed or denied)
  • Launchpad Tile (allowed or denied)

Key SAP Modules and What They Do

1Ô∏è SAP Financial Accounting (FI)

It captures every financial transaction across and within the organization. It helps manage financial records and supports the business in financial decision making.

General Ledger

  • It this every crucial part that holds financial information such as Bank statement and balance sheet like database.

Accounts Payable (AP)

  • It manages the payment for suppliers and records the financial activity between supplier and organization.
  • It handles credit memos, invoices, and reporting

Accounts Receivable (AR)

  • It manages the money that comes into the company, for example, customer payments for a car.

Asset Accounting

  • Fixed asset that used throughout the organization for managing the company example chairs, laptops etc.
  • The lifecycle of entire Asset Accounting is acquisition, depreciation and Retirement. Acquisition is records the purchase of machinery, lease the building etc., depreciation is calculation decrease period the purchased asset for the company and retirement is disposing the Asset.

Bank Accounting

  • It helps to Manages bank statements, payments, and reconciliation.

Procure to Pay (P2P):

Procure to Pay (P2P) is an end-to-end business process that begin with purchasing goods and services and ends with vendor payment. It integrates procurement process and finance functions, ensuring purchasing operations and timely supplier payments to record. It starts with a Purchase Requisition, which is a request for goods and services. After that, an order is created and the material is dispatched. Once the item is dispatched, it must be received in the inventory, and the system should be updated with the details of what materials and how many units were received. After that, the invoice is collected, and finally, the payment is processed.

In SAP, P2P is primarily handled through the MM and FI where procurement process is managed and Payments are processed.

2Ô∏è SAP Controlling (CO)

It handles overall cost spending of the company that tracks internal costs, internal project, external project cast and monitors company spending etc.

Key Components:

  • Profit Centre Accounting: It tracks profit of the organization 
  • Cost Centre Accounting: It Monitors departmental expenses
  • Internal Orders: It tracks cost of the internal project
  • Product Costing: It calculates the cost of the product.
  • Profitability Analysis: Analysis the profit based on the region and customer

Record to Report (R2R)

The below image provided the Record to Report (R2R) process in SAP operations. R2R refers to the end-to-end process of recording transactions, closing financial periods, and generating reports for stakeholders. It records the every transaction and report the transaction finally.

It provides a structured approach to capturing the business transaction, Jornal Entries and sub ledger updates, Month end year end closing activities, financial report of balance sheet and tax reports, check accounting accuracy, closing books efficiently, and reporting. 

3Ô∏è SAP Sales & Distribution (SD)

Sales Distribution it very essential part of sales process it track from sale of the car to billing by the customer.

It initiates with the pre-sales process, which involves inquiries about the product and receiving quotations. After that, the customer decides whether to proceed with the purchase. Once confirmed, a sales order is created. After finalizing contracts and agreements, the process moves to the delivery stage. Required documents are prepared, items are picked from inventory, packed, and shipped to the specified address. Finally, the order is billed based on the invoice, payment is received, and the order is considered dispatched.

Integration Example:

The sales part integrate with both FI and MM part 

  • Sales Order Creation
    • Checks stock availability in MM
    • Runs credit checks in FI

4Ô∏è SAP Material Management (MM)

It insures the material availability throughout the lifecycle.

Procurement Lifecycle:

Material procurement in SAP MM (Materials Management) encompasses the complete lifecycle of acquiring goods and services from external suppliers, using MM we can manage all procurement activity. SAP MM equips organizations with tools to streamline and manage procurement activities efficiently. Below is a simple steps involved:

  1. Initiating Purchase Requisition (PR) - It is the process that creating purchase requisition as an internal request to procure the goods and services. It can be either manually or automatically based on availability.
  2. Issuing Request for Quotation (RFQ) - If it external an RFQ is generated and sent to selected vendors it helps to prepare RFQ to suppliers.
  3. Evaluating Vendor Quotations
    Once vendors respond, quotations are evaluated within SAP MM If it external an RFQ is generated based on some criteria like cost, quality and time taken for delivery.
  4. Creating Purchase Order (PO)
    Once vendor selection is completed, a purchase order is created containing all procurement detail such as quantity, pricing, delivery schedule, and payment terms.
  5. Recording Goods Receipt (GR)
    Delivery, a goods receipt is entered in SAP MM. This step confirms receipt and automatically updates inventory levels. It records every detail about the goods.
  6. Invoice Verification
    Following the Good Receipt, the vendor submits an invoice. SAP MM supports three-way matching  invoice, Purchase order, Goods Receipt to validate before forwarding it for payment.
  7. Processing Payments
    Verified invoices are handed off to SAP FI for payment processing, ensuring vendors are paid as per agreed terms also records any money balance.
  8. Vendor Performance Evaluation
    Visit the vendor‚Äôs location to evaluate the quality and safety standards and determine whether to continue working with the vendor in the future.
  9. Maintaining Material Master Data
    It has complete data of vendors such as vendor details, and pricing is crucial throughout the procurement process.
  10. Utilizing Reports & Analytics
    SAP MM offers powerful reporting tools to track procurement performance and identify the place to optimize and efficient.

 Inventory & Physical Stock Management:

  • Physically goods are stored and managed here.

Source to Pay (S2P):

Source to Pay (S2P) is a process for finding and managing suitable suppliers to purchase goods and services. It involves supplier identification and providing the RFQ. Once bid evaluation is completed, contract negotiation begins, and the requisition is approved. After that, a purchase order (PO) is created, goods receipt (GR) is generated, inventory is updated, and finally, the invoice is verified and payment is processed.

5Ô∏è SAP Production Planning (PP)

SAP Production Planning (PP) module is used to help plan manufacturing for sales and distribution of products.

.

 Manufacturing Types:

  • Repetitive Manufacturing: products stay the same over a long period of time
  • Discrete Manufacturing:  product is customize or change frequently

Key Components:

  • Bill of Materials (BOM): Complete list of the material and assemblies needed to manufacture a product
  • Routing: routing used for finished or semi-finished product calculate operation cost for finished product.
  • Capacity Planning: Used to balance production across different work centre.
  • Material Requirement Planning (MRP): Ensures material is available, key feature of MRP is that when it run, it will create procurement proposals. It ensures production can happen to meet our demand and it minimize the cost of holding too much unnecessary inventory.

6Ô∏è SAP Quality Management (QM)

SAP Quality Management deals with managing quality throughout a company‚Äôs processes.

Key Processes:

  • Quality Inspection: determine if the units inspected meet defined quality requirement.
    • Unit quality is measured.
    • Result and defect recording
  • Quality Control: Preventive, Monitoring and corrective actions
  • Quality Notifications: It involves in Record poor quality of internal or external issues. It can be created anywhere in the product cycle. This includes incoming inspection when a product has been purchased externally and final inspection before sending finished products out to our customers. It measures and monitor the quality against

7Ô∏è SAP Plant Maintenance (PM)

SAP Plant maintenance to manage the equipment and infrastructure of the plant.

Inspection: Measures condition of a production area.

Preventive maintenance: Maintains condition of a production area.

Repair: Restore condition of a production area.

8Ô∏è SAP Project System (PS)

SAP Project System that enables companies to manage all projects, large or small scale throughout the project lifecycle. It includes project planning, execution and completion.

Internal financed projects ‚Äì funded by company themselves.

External financed projects ‚Äì sponsored by clients and are executed to meet client requirement.

Key components of PS:

  • WBS (Work Breakdown Structure)
    • Shows amount of work
    • Shows how long.
    • Shows cost involved.
  • Once work breakdown is calculated, we‚Äôre able to accurately begin process planning, cost planning, scheduling and date and capacity planning.

9Ô∏è SAP Human Capital Management (HCM)

SAP HCM is a comprehensive solution designed to Manage all human resource and all these functions rely on organizational management.

Organizational Management: Where organizational populated, with different areas, position, and employee names.

Employee Administration: Which handle employee address, bank details and tax information.

Time Management: To record attendance, shift management and leave.

Benefits Management: Where companies can create their own unique benifit packages.

Recruitment: Includes Application tracking and reporting.

Learning Management: It helps enable online training and to track the completion of course by employees.

SAP Navigation for End Users

Clients

  • Different clients = different environments (e.g., 100, 110 etc‚Ä¶)

Transaction Codes (T-Codes)

  • Shortcut commands for SAP tasks
  • Ending with:
    • 01: Create
    • 02: Change
    • 03: Display
  • Starting with:
    • Y or Z: Custom codes
  • /n ‚Üí Open transaction in the same session
  • /o ‚Üí Open transaction in a new session

Conclusion: The SAP Advantage ‚Äì Integration and Efficiency Across Functions

SAP ERP modules are the principal of enterprise systems, integrating various business processes across organization. Whether it's managing FI (Financial Accounting), MM (Material Mangement), SD (Sales and Distribution) Modules and etc. Processes like Source to Pay (S2P), Procure to Pay (P2P), Record to Report (R2R) and Order to cash (O2C) demonstrate the inter connection of strategic and operational activities within an organization. With SAP‚Äôs modular approach, businesses can achieve efficiency process the overall lifecycle of the product so and so, accuracy, and transparency across their procurement and finance functions. By understanding the process and how it works throughout the organization, you can make decisions based on the data collected during the process, which increases the performance of the organization.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP SuccessFactors HCM: Highlights from SAP Sapphire 2025
entry.content:
Top Takeaways for HR Leaders from SAP Sapphire 2025

SAP Sapphire 2025 delivered a bold message, the future of Human Capital Management (HCM) is intelligent, agile, and AI-powered. With new product launches, strategic pivots, and major updates across analytics, service delivery, and digital adoption, SAP is leading the next evolution of HR transformation.

These innovations draw on SAP‚Äôs unparalleled integration of business data and enterprise-grade AI - helping HR leaders make smarter decisions, deliver better experiences, and connect people strategy to business success like never before.

Discover what‚Äôs next in human capital management and what it means for your team.

Key Innovations in SAP SuccessFactors HCM

1. People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud

Announced during Dan Beck‚Äôs HCM keynote, People Intelligence is SAP's next-generation people analytics platform, now integrated with the SAP Business Data Cloud. This solution unifies people and skills data from SAP SuccessFactors with broader business datasets, turning it into actionable, AI-powered insights for HR and business leaders.

Highlights:

  • Self-service, business-friendly interface

  • Hundreds of HR KPIs and AI-based forecasts

  • Governed, enriched workforce data for decision-making

  • Joule copilot integration for instant answers

People Intelligence shall go General Availability sometime in Q3 2025.
Target audience: EC + Workforce Analytics customers aligning with SAP's analytics stack.

2. Performance and Goals Agent

The new Performance and Goals Agent is designed to supercharge the employee-manager relationship. The Performance and Goals Agent aims to enhance performance management by equipping managers with the information they need to have productive and insightful conversations with their team members. 

 
Functionality:
The agent utilizes data-driven insights to help managers identify areas for improvement, highlight employee strengths, and tailor development plans.

Availability:
While the agent was announced at SAP Sapphire 2025, its general availability is planned for Q4 2025. 

3. WalkMe for SAP SuccessFactors HCM

In collaboration with WalkMe, SAP SuccessFactors now features AI-powered in-app guidance across key workflows like onboarding and time-off requests.

Key capabilities:

  • Click-by-click user journey tracking

  • AI-powered step-by-step support and automation

  • Built-in guides for onboarding, compliance, and training

  • Customizable packages for enterprise-wide digital adoption

Availability: Embedded by default effective 1H 2025, with upgrade options to Platform and Premium WalkMe licenses.

4. SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management

Replacing the legacy ECSC (Employee Central Service Center), this new solution delivers purpose-built, AI-powered HR case management and self-service. This new solution brings AI-based case management and self-service HR capabilities into one unified experience.

Features:

  • Intelligent case routing and prioritization with Joule AI

  • Customized case flows for complex HR scenarios

  • Proactive support and sentiment analysis

  • Seamless integration with Employee Central master data

Availability: SKU is now active. ECSC customers will need reimplementation; migration tools and support are in development.

5. New SAP Business Suite Packages for HCM

To further accelerate transformation, SAP is introducing modular SAP Business Suite Packages for HCM. These are pre-integrated bundles of HR capabilities built on SAP BTP that simplify implementation and reduce time-to-value.

These packages provide integrated solutions across:

  • Core HR

  • Workforce planning and analytics

  • HR service delivery

  • AI and automation

Packages allow HR teams to:

  • Choose capabilities based on current needs
  • Scale and integrate easily over time
  • Leverage the full power of SAP Business AI and analytics

Ideal for CHROs looking for a fast, scalable route to value with deep integration and extensibility.

Key Takeaways for HR Leaders

  • AI that Drives Impact: SAP‚Äôs embedded AI enables HR teams to make decisions faster and with confidence.
  • Smarter, More Engaged Employees: Tools like WalkMe and the Performance Agent create better experiences and improve adoption.
  • Data-Driven Workforce Strategy: People Intelligence empowers leaders to align skills, roles, and resources with business strategy.
  • Faster, Simpler Transformation: SAP‚Äôs modular HCM packages reduce complexity and help teams move quickly from planning to value realization.

Final Thoughts

Your best. Made real. Powered by SAP SuccessFactors.

In an era marked by constant change and workforce uncertainty, SAP‚Äôs latest HCM innovations offer a roadmap for resilient, data-driven HR transformation.

By combining AI, people insights, and enterprise integration, SAP SuccessFactors continues to set the benchmark for modern HCM ‚Äî helping organizations around the world not only keep up, but lead the way forward.

For a complete view of all innovations announced at SAP Sapphire 2025, visit the:
SAP Sapphire 2025 Innovation Guide

entry.title: Creation of Deep Links in SuccessFactors Suites
entry.content:
üì¢What is Deep Link ?  üì¢ It is a hyperlink that helps the system users / those newly experiencing the system for the first time to navigate to the precise target location of user Information/company Information out of the crowded system details, so you will not be lost. You can place this link anywhere on your company website / Emails / external systems by clicking on it will drive you to the desired location, even in the SuccessFactors home page (tiles/cards) or in the main navigation menu.

üó£üîäWhat does 1H-2025 say on the Deep link for those who opted (PPX UI Experience) - SAP recommend that to configure deep links to cards or categories and stop using legacy block deep links in your system. Currently, only certain block deep links containing block types can be resolved for the latest People Profile.

PP3 UI (Legacy People Profile Experience)

PPX UI (Latest People Profile)

BLOCKS

Categories

Portlets

Summary Cards

 

üë®‚Äçüè´What are all the Data elements that comprise forming complete Deep links? 

1.Domain Name - Name used by the application server, you can make use of this information from the browser URL, (Tip ‚Äì Make use of data before ‚Äú/‚Äù), and it varies by customer and region (https://hcm-eu10-sales.hr.cloud.sap)

2.Deep link Path üõ£ ‚Äì True deep links begin with ‚Äú/sf/‚Äù and deep link paths are the first filter and navigation definition of the data/location, where the user would like to navigate to. Deep link would vary based on the location/destination/sf-module of the data where we need to land the user. Currently, we are exploring the employee profile information, so our Deep link path would be ‚Äúsf/liveprofile‚Äù.

Tip üí° ‚Äì We can‚Äôt define the Deep link path on our own, it was pre-defined by the SAP for the different modules and based on the nature of data where the deep link is supported, please find the link for more Deep Link path on your business requirement SAP Help Portal - Deep Links

3.Parameters ‚Äì After Deep Link path, parameters which help for the fine-granular navigation refinement with the help of data (i.e. Key value pair) which directs the user to the destination page where we are expecting the user to land üõ¨. Also, the parameter values vary based on the nature of the data we are trying to land  üõ¨.

  • CategoryId = personalData , jobData , compensation
  • cardId = personalInfo, jobInfo , oneTimePayment
  • username= John123

 

4.Separators ‚Äì There are different separators based on the nature of the parameters we are trying to separate it, they are ( ‚Äú/‚Äù , ‚Äú&‚Äù , ‚Äú?‚Äù , ‚Äú#‚Äù)

 

  • /  - Character serves as a path separator within the URL, much like it does in standard web URLs. Separates the main deep link path ( /sf/) from the specific action or page you're targeting.

  • ? ‚Äì Act as the separator between the base URL and parameters (To recall parameters please refer to the point no 3)

 

  • & -  Acts as a separator between different parameters or key-value pairs within a URL.

 

  • # - Act as an anchor in the URL, which helps to direct the user to a specific section or element within the page. 

Configured Deeplink :

‚Äì Straight Navigation to Personal Data

 

Further granular navigation to Personal Information Detail Page.

Further, you can flip (or) change the values as per your navigation requirements.

entry.title: Story Performance Analysis Tool in Report Center: New in 1H 2025!
entry.content:
Overview

The recent enhancements to the People Analytics module for the 1H 2025 have proven to be highly impactful. A particularly noteworthy enhancement is the ability to assess and optimize the efficiency of Story reports.

The Story Performance Analysis Tool, accessible via Report Center, enables Story administrators to assess, monitor, measure and optimize the efficiency of Story reports and captures detailed performance metrics, helping identify areas for improvement and enhance overall report performance. This enhancement aims to bring greater visibility and control over the performance aspects of Stories.

Benefits of Story Performance Analysis Tool: -

The Story Performance Analysis Tool delivers significant value to various user groups, including HR administrators, managers, and analytics power users:

  • For Administrators:

- Helps identify bottlenecks or inefficiencies in report design or data handling and minimizes report loading delays
- Allows for proactive performance tuning, such as optimizing filters, chart components, or data models.
- Reduces reliance on IT teams by giving admins tools to self-diagnose issues.

  •  For End Users (Managers, HRBPs, etc.):

- Ensures faster access to performance-critical reports and improves data-driven decision-making ensuring reports load reliably.
- Leads to a better user experience with less waiting time and smoother navigation.

  • Overall Organizational Benefits:

- Saves time and effort by eliminating guesswork around report performance issues.
- Helps maintain reporting integrity and reliability in strategic HR processes like performance management, compensation reviews.

What You‚Äôll Need:-

For successful utilization of this enhancement, make sure:

  • You have access to Stories in Report Center.
  • You have the Role-Based Permission Prerequisites: - Administrator > Manage Dashboards/Reports > Story Admin

Now let‚Äôs walk through the Procedure to utilize the Story Performance Analysis Tool: -

Step 1.  To access the Performance Analysis Tool, choose Story Performance Analysis Tool from the Report Center.

 

Landing Page of the Performance Analysis Tool:-

Step 2.  To set the date range:

  1. Click the Session Date token.
  2. Adjust the existing range or add a new range.

Step 3.  To apply additional filters:

  1. Click on User or Resource
  2. Select the appropriate member(s).

Step 4.  In the list of results, click to select the report/item to analyze.

 

The report is analyzed in 3 sections namely -

  • Summary
  • Details
  • History

a.) Summary Section

The Summary section provides a top-level overview of the total performance footprint of the Story report. It captures the end-to-end load time, determine where high-level delays are occurring and distributes it across the 3 primary system layers involved in report execution:

 Network ‚Äì Time spent in data transfer between the server and the client

 Backend ‚Äì Time taken to retrieve and prepare data from the data model

Frontend ‚Äì Time taken to render charts, tables, and visuals on the user interface.

- Under Summary section,

  • Startup Time displays ‚Äì The Timespan from the initiation of the Actions "Open" and "Go to Page to the finalized page.
  • Total Widget Time displays ‚Äì The sum of all usage times for each Widget, including multiple uses.
  • Maximum Backend Duration displays ‚Äì The maximum backend processing time per model, noting totals may rise with multiple widgets or refreshes. 
  • Maximum Widget Time and Total Widget Time displays ‚Äì Maximum and median processing times per layer (frontend, backend, network) across all widgets during user interactions

 

b.) Details Section

The Details section provides a granular breakdown of performance data, offering visibility into how specific report components contribute to overall load time. This includes: - Performance of individual pages within the Story, Load time of specific widgets, such as charts, graphs, or tables, Execution time for backend queries, including filtering, sorting, and data transformation

It is used by admins to troubleshoot performance bottlenecks and identifies exact sources of delay, facilitates targeted optimizations, reduces trial-and-error during report tuning.

- Under Details section,

  • Page Load Time displays ‚Äì Total load time per story page, split by phase, with peak backend, frontend, and network times
  • Widget Drilldown displays ‚Äì Widget load time with action, page, model, and backend request details.
  • Loading Sequence displays - Widget load time by action, split into backend, network, and frontend

 

c.) History Section

The History section records a time-stamped log of previous performance analyses conducted on the same Story report. It enables comparison of performance metrics across different test runs or after configuration changes.

It supports trend analysis and performance benchmarking over time and tracks performance improvements or regressions, provides historical evidence of tuning efforts, supports continuous monitoring for business-critical reports

Under History section,

  • Total Time per Date displays ‚Äì Charts compare a user's performance history with others, switching measures based on filters like page, action, or widget.
  • Runtime Split per Date displays ‚Äì Charts compare a single user‚Äôs runtime performance (median backend, network, frontend times) against all users, independent of filters.

 

Step 5.  Take Action Based on Insights: -

  1. Optimize charts and pages with high frontend time.
  2. Adjust or reduce filters and calculations affecting backend time.
  3. Collaborate with your technical team if network issues persist.

Administrators/Users also have the option ‚Äì

  • To enable the Show in Milliseconds toggle which will display the Time in milliseconds
  • To apply filters as per the requirement

You've reached the end of this process!

With minimal effort, administrators can directly access Story Performance Analysis Tool within Report Center, enhancing ability to assess and optimize the efficiency of Story reports and identifying areas for improvement and optimize report performance.

entry.title: Enable Social Login & 2FA for External Candidates in SAP SuccessFactors via SAP Customer Data Cloud
entry.content:
In Q4 2024, SAP SuccessFactors introduced a robust authentication mechanism for external candidates through SAP Customer Data Cloud (CDC). This enhancement delivers a fast, seamless, and secure login experience by enabling job seekers to login using email, phone number, or social credentials (such as Google or LinkedIn), while supporting two-factor authentication (2FA) for added security.

This blog provides a step-by-step guide to help you configure social login providers and 2FA for external candidates on your SAP SuccessFactors career site using the SAP CDC Console.

Overview of the Social Provider Integration Process

The integration involves three primary steps:

  1. Registering an Application with the social media provider

  2. Configuring the Identity Provider in SAP Customer Data Cloud

  3. Enabling the Social Login in the UI Builder of the SAP CDC Console

While steps 2 and 3 are consistent across providers, step 1 varies depending on the platform. Below are detailed instructions for Google and LinkedIn, followed by high-level guidelines for other providers.

A. Google Login Setup

Step 1: Register an application with Google

1.1 Access Google Cloud Console
Navigate to https://console.cloud.google.com and either create a new project or select an existing one.


1.2 Enable the Google People API

Go to API & Services > Library, search for Google People API, and click Enable. 

 

1.3 Create OAuth Credentials

Click Create Credentials and follow the next steps.


 

1.3.1 Credential Type

Under "What data will you be accessing", select the "User Data" radio button. 

1.3.2 Configure OAuth Consent Screen

Provide the following details :

  • App name (e.g., Candidate Login App)

  • App logo (mandatory; tools like Adobe Express can help)

  • Developer contact email

 

1.3.3 Scopes

This section is optional and can be skipped.

1.3.4 Configure OAuth Client ID

  • Application Type: Web Application

  • Name: A name for the credential (e.g., Google Login)

  • Authorized JavaScript origins: Use the base URL of your SAP SuccessFactors Career Site, such as:

    https://career68sales.successfactors.com

  • Authorized Redirect URIs:

    https://socialize.gigya.com/GS/GSLogin.aspx?  (Mandatory)
    https://socialize.<DataCenter>/GS/GSLogin.aspx? - 
    Replace the "DataCenter" field using the below link(e.g., https://socialize.us1.gigya.com/GS/GSLogin.aspx?)
    Ensure to include the trailing question mark (?) ‚Äî it is required for successful redirects. Refer to Finding your Data Center to find the details of your data center.

1.3.5 Download and Note Your Credentials

Once completed, you'll be shown the Client ID and Client Secret ‚Äî save these securely, as you'll need them in the next step when configuring CDC.

Step 2: Configure Google as an Identity Provider in SAP CDC

  1. Open the Identity Providers page of SAP Customer Data Cloud's Console.
  2. From the list of Identity Providers, select Google.
  3. Click on Google to open its configuration window.


  4. In the Google Configuration window enter:

    • Your "Client ID" from the Google Developers Dashboard into the "Consumer Key" field. (The entire string, including .apps.googleusercontent.com)
    • Your "Client Secret" into the "Secret Key" field.
    • Select Secure redirects only to allow only HTTPS redirects from Google.

Step 3: Enable Google Login in SAP CDC UI Builder

By default, the Login & Registration screen-set on the career site displays only basic authentication (email and password). To display the Social Login widget, follow these steps:

  1. Select a screen-set: Choose either the Registration or Login screen-set where you want to enable social login.

  2. In the Properties section:

    • Remove the gigya-hidden CSS class from the social widget (and also for the separator elements in the Login screen).

    • In the Supported Providers field, enter a comma-separated list of the social login providers to display ‚Äî for example: googleplus,linkedin,facebook

These changes will make the Google social provider visible to external candidates on the career site.

B. LinkedIn Login Setup

Step 1: Register an Application with LinkedIn

  1. Visit the LinkedIn Developer Portal.

  2. Create a new app and fill in the required details.



  3. Request access for sign in with linkedIn using openId connect



  4.  Navigate to the Auth tab and set the below Redirect URLs :

    4.1) The URL should be in the format "https://socialize.<DataCenter>/GS/GSLogin.aspx?" where  <DataCenter> can be found out using     Finding your Data Center.  Be sure to include the trailing question mark (?)  as it is required for successful redirects.

    4.2) The URL of your career site - for example, https://career68sales.successfactors.com



  5.  Under Settings -> Additional settings, add the above redirect URL's domain (ex. "https://socialize.us1.gigya.com")
    and that of your career site (ex. https://career68sales.successfactors.com)


  6. Save and note the Client ID and Client Secret, as these will be used in the next step.

Step 2: Configure LinkedIn as an Identity Provider in SAP CDC

  1. Open the Identity Providers page of SAP Customer Data Cloud's Console.

  2. Select LinkedIn from the list of supported providers.

  3. Paste your LinkedIn "API Key (Client ID)" and "Secret Key (Client Secret)" in the corresponding fields.

  4. Select Secure redirects only to allow only HTTPS redirects from Linkedin.
  5. Select Application Type as "Sign In with LinkedIn using OpenID Connect"
  6. Select the permission "Enable retrieving email address".

Step 3: Enable Linkedin Login in the SAP CDC UI Builder

By default, the Login & Registration screen-set on the career site displays only basic authentication (email and password). To display the Social Login widget, follow these steps:

  1. Select a screen-set: Choose either the Registration or Login screen-set where you want to enable social login.

  2. In the Properties section:

    • Remove the "gigya-hidden" CSS class from the social widget (and also for the separator elements in the Login screen).

    • In the Supported Providers field, enter a comma-separated list of the social login providers to display ‚Äî for example: googleplus,linkedin,facebook

These changes will make the Linkedin social provider visible to external candidates on the career site.

Extending to Other Social Login Providers

The process for integrating other social login providers, such as Facebook, Twitter, Apple, or GitHub, follows a similar pattern:‚Äã

  1. Register an application with the respective provider to obtain the necessary credentials.

  2. Configure the provider in the SAP CDC Console by entering the required credentials from the application.

  3. Enable the provider in the SAP CDC Console's UI Builder to make it available as a login option.‚Äã

For detailed guidance on integrating additional providers, refer to the SAP Customer Data Cloud documentation.‚Äã

Enabling Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) in SAP Customer Data Cloud

Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) enhances login security by requiring users to verify their identity through a second method, such as email, SMS, or an authenticator app. SAP Customer Data Cloud supports all three options.

Follow the steps below to enable 2FA for external candidates in SAP SuccessFactors using SAP CDC:

Step 1: Enable Email Identity Verification (Required for Email 2FA)

Before enabling email-based 2FA, ensure email identity verification is active:

  1. Navigate to Identity ‚Üí Security in the CDC Console.

  2. Open the Identity Verification tab.

  3. In the Email Verification section:

    • Select Require email verification.

    • Enable Use code verification to require users to enter a code from the verification email.

  4. Click Save.

Step 2: Enable 2FA Authentication Methods

Go to Identity ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Authentication and, under Verification Methods, enable your preferred 2FA options:

  • Email ‚Äì Check Email and click Save.

    Requires email verification to be enabled (see Step 1).

  • SMS/Phone ‚Äì Check SMS/Phone and click Save.

    Ensure an SMS provider is configured.

  • Authenticator App ‚Äì Check Authenticator App, enter a name (e.g., SAP Login Authenticator), and click Save.

    Users need an app like Google or Microsoft Authenticator installed.

Step 3: Create a Risk-Based Authentication (RBA) Rule

To apply the 2FA methods during login, set up a Risk-Based Authentication rule:

  1. Open the Risk Based Authentication tab under Identity-> Security in the CDC Console.

  2. Click on Create New Rule, select the template "Enforce TFA for Every Login" and click Next

  3. Provide a rule name and select "Password Login" as the trigger condition.


  4. Under Rule type, select "Global Rule" and define the required criteria below.

  5. In the Actions section, select the 2FA method(s) to enforce (Email, SMS, Authenticator App).

  6. Click Next and set the Scope to apply to the whole group.

  7. Save the Rule.

Once configured, candidates logging in with their credentials will be prompted for an additional verification step, depending on the methods you‚Äôve enabled.

Additional References

For a high-level overview, prerequisites, and benefits of using SAP Customer Data Cloud, refer to the blog.

For detailed information on migrating and enabling SAP CDC for Success Factors Candidate Authentication, refer to the blog.
